findings.title: API keys are leaked outside of the application server
findings.description: API key verification is handled by the `AuthKey` function which passes the plaintext value of a key to the database as part of the database query, leaking API keys outside of the application server.

findings.title: Unused insecure authentication mechanism
findings.description: The `clap` code contains an unused insecure authentication mechanism, the `FixedKeyAuther` strategy, that stores configured plaintext keys and verifies them through a non-constant-time comparison, creating a timing attack risk.

findings.title: Use of panics to handle user-triggerable errors
findings.description: The system generally adheres to Go error-handling conventions. However, we identified unnecessary uses of panics to handle user-triggerable errors.

findings.title: Confusing API authentication mechanism
findings.description: API key verification is handled by the `AuthKey` function which uses the `auth` method, passing plaintext value of a key to the database as part of the database query.

findings.title: Use of MD5 can lead to filename collisions
findings.description: When generating a filename, the deriveQueueFile function uses an unsafe MD5 hash function to hash the destinationID that is included in the filename.

findings.title: Overly broad file permissions
findings.description: In several parts of the `ae` code, files are created with overly broad permissions that allow them to be read by anyone in the system.

findings.title: Unhandled errors
findings.description: The `gosec` tool identified many unhandled errors in the `ae` and `clap` codebases.
